transcript.title: FOR PRESS: PM. NO. 24/1969 - MRS. HOFFMANS STORY - COMMENT BY THE PRIME MINISTER, MR JOHN GORTON
transcript.content:
FOR PRESS 3i:
PM4L No. 24/ 1969
MRS. HOFFMANN'S STORY
Comment by the Prime Minister, Mr John Gorton
In accordance with established practice, the
Government has consistently refused in Parliament either to confirm
or deny that Mrs Hoffmann did any work for ASLO at the Japanese
Embassy eight years ago.
Again, in accordance with that practice, I do not
propose either to confirm or deny the truth of Mrs Hoffmanns
published story. But the reported comments of Mr Whitlam and
Senator Murphy on the matter appear to me to be both hysterical
and ludicrous. If the story is not true, it can be disregarded. If
it is true, then it shows that as a result of attempted espionage and
bribery against Australia' s interests, Mrs Hoffmann engaged in
counter espionage in Australia' s interests.
Surely no Australian cculd object to that except
apparently Mr Whitlam and his Parliamentary colleagues of the Labor
Party. By their objections I think that they do Australia
a disservice. But this is neither to confirm wr deny Mrs Hoffmann's
story itself.
CANBERRA, 8 March 1969
